title: A Life-Stage Guide to Coping in Volatile Markets
text:
You probably don’t give a lot of thought to the market’s daily fluctuations. What matters is the long haul, after all.

But when the bad days start to outnumber the good ones, it’s hard not to worry a little bit. Should you follow the exhortation to “Don’t just do something, stand there!”? Or does serious market volatility warrant corrective action to reduce your exposure to risky assets?

The right answer is looking right back at you in the mirror. Life stage and proximity to spending from your portfolio should be the main determinant of whether you take action amid a volatile market. If you’re many years from retirement, you can and should go the “just stand there” route, assuming you were in a reasonably equity-heavy portfolio to begin with. If you’re not spooked by putting money into a declining market, you may even add to your equity holdings during a downturn. But if retirement is drawing close, or if you’re already retired, the right prescription may not be to do nothing; taking action to reduce risk in your portfolio may be the right call.

Psychology is in the mix, too. Even if you have many years until retirement, that doesn’t count for a lot if there’s a chance that you could capitulate at the worst conceivable time because you’re spooked. You’ll also want to factor in any nonretirement goals you have for your funds; chances are they’re shorter-term, and that calls for a lower-risk investment mix.

Finally, given that serious market weakness is often precipitated by concerns over the economy’s health, market volatility can be a wake-up call to check up on other parts of your financial plan. That includes your saving/spending rate, your short-term cash reserves (that is, your emergency fund), your insurance coverage, and your human capital, among other items.

Because responding to volatile markets is so variable and individual-specific, we’ve organized articles and other tools to help guide you based on life stage. Folks with 15 to 20 years until retirement can head straight to the “If You're Many Years From Retirement” section, whereas people entering or in drawdown mode can focus on the action items geared toward their situations.
